Company: General American Life Insurance Company, Inc.
Description: General American Life Insurance Company, Inc. agreed to pay $76 million to settle allegations that it submitted false information to the Medicare program. The company also agreed to  refrain from seeking business with Medicare for a five-year period.
The settlement included a $5 million fund for the plaintiffs and a commitment to spend another $5 million on monitoring, training and recruitment.
Private Litigation Case Title: Mitchell, et al v. Metropolitan Life

Description: The Federal Reserve Board announced the issuance of monetary sanctions totaling $3.2 million against MetLife, Inc. for failure to adequately oversee its subsidiary bank's mortgage loan servicing and foreclosure processing operations.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Ten mortgage servicing companies subject to enforcement actions for deficient practices in mortgage loan servicing and foreclosure processing reached an agreement in principle with the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve Board to pay more than $8.5 billion in cash payments and other assistance to help borrowers.
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: MetLife Home Loans LLC agreed to pay $123.5 million to resolve allegations of violating the False Claims Act by knowingly originating and underwriting mortgage loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration that did not meet applicable requirements.
overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Brandon Johnson v. Metlife Inc et al

Description: misclassification
Private Litigation Case Title: Patricia Wyler-Wittenberg v. Metlife Home Loans, Inc. et al

Description: off-the-clock work
Private Litigation Case Title: Robert Cerami v. Metlife Inc et al

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Visci et al v. Metlife Bank et al
TATE v. METROPOLITAN LIFE INSURANCE COMPANY

Description: misclassification
Private Litigation Case Title: Neil Weinstein, et al. v.?Metlife?Inc., et al.

Description: Racial discrimination.
Private Litigation Case Title: Creighton v. Metlife Securities, Inc. et al
Magliulo v. Metropolitan Life, et al

Description: MetLife agreed to pay $40 million to settle multistate litigation regarding its use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.
Info Source: Pennsylvania Protects Life Insurance Beneficiaries in MetLife Settlement, States News Service, April 23, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: Metlife agreed to pay $150,000 and extend life insurance benefits for consumers in settlement of allegations of unfair and deceptive practices in selling its variable-life policies.
Agreed to pay $1.2 million in settlement of allegations its life insurance sales practices were unfair and deceptive.

Met Life agreed to pay $16.5 million in restitution and $2.5 million in penalties to resolve an investigation of deceptive practices in its compensation of brokers and consultants in connection with the sale of group insurance products.

Metropolitan Life Insurance, Prudential Insurance Co. and Unum Insurance Co. agreed to pay a total of $1.1 million in settlement of allegations by three California District Attorneys that they paid illegal rebates to a brokerage firm to obtain business.

MetLife agreed to pay $10 million in a Deferred Prosecution Agreement settling allegations it violated New York Insurance Law and the New York Penal Law for by operating two subsidiaries that did not pay for insurance licensing.

Metropolitan agreed to pay $700,000 in costs in settlement of allegations it violated insurance regulations by failing to disclose details of compensation and contingent compensation for the Producer representing the policyholder.

Agency: District of Columbia Department of Insurance, Securities and Banking

Description: MetLife agreed to pay a $1 million administrative penalty in settlement of allegations it had not taken sufficient steps to locate pension beneficiaries, and that its treatment of unclaimed pensions led them to make inaccurate financial reports.

Company: MetLife Investors USA Insurance Co. et al.
Description: MetLife Investors USA Insurance Co. agreed to pay a $250,000 civil penalty in settlement of allegations it improperly issued and allowed to be sold Oregon form annuity contracts to Minnesota residents.

Company: MetLife Investors USA Insurance Co. et al.
Description: MetLife  Investors USA Insurance Co., First MetLife  Investors Insurance Company, Delaware American Life Insurance Company, General American Life Insurance Company, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company,  Safehealth Life Insurance Company, MetLife Insurance Company of Connecticut, New England Life Insurance Company, MetLife  Investors Insurance Company, and  Metropolitan Tower Life Insurance Company agreed to pay a $200,000 civil penalty in settlement of allegations their previous use of the automatic default option establishing a retained asset account could result in an unsuitable arrangement for a beneficiary, in violation of state regulations.

MetLife, Inc, Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., New England Life Insurance Co., MetLife Insurance Co. of Connecticut, General American Life Insurance Co., Metropolitan Tower Life Insurance Co., Metlife Investors USA Insurance Co., and Delaware American Life Insurance Co. agreed to pay $1.5 million to the state as part of a settlement of allegations they had inadequate procedures to ensure policies and other funds were timely investigated and paid out to beneficiaries.

The Department of Financial Services announced that MetLife would pay a $50 million penalty for Insurance Law and other violations at its subsidiaries ALICO and DelAm, which it acquired from AIG in 2010. An investigation uncovered that those subsidiaries solicited insurance business in New York without a license and made intentional misrepresentations and omissions to DFS about those activities.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with MetLife Insurance Company, under which the insurer agereed to pay a penalty of $19,750,000 for violations of New York Insurance Law stemming from a DFS examination which found that the insurer failed to properly locate and pay benefits to thousands of New York insureds and beneficiaries. As part of the consent order, MetLife also agreed to pay retroactive benefits to policyholders in New York State and elsewhere totaling more than $189 million.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
Rhode Island Department of Business Regulation

Description: Fine levied for failing to calculate coordination of benefits amount due to enrollees in accordance with WAC 284-51.230. RCW 48-05.185; WAC 284-51-230; 284-51-190(2)
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: Company fined for failure to pay the correct death claim settlement. RCW 48.23.300.
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $7,000 fine levied for offering an illegal inducement in the form of an implementation credit to the insured, thereby violating RCW 48.30.140(1); RCW 48.18.100.
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner
Wisconsin Office of the Commissioner of Insurance

Description: race-based underwriting
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined MetLife Securities, Inc. (MSI) $20 million and ordered it to pay $5 million to customers for making negligent material misrepresentations and omissions on variable annuity (VA) replacement applications for tens of thousands of customers. Each misrepresentation and omission made the replacement appear more beneficial to the customer, even though the recommended VAs were typically more expensive than customers' existing VAs.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered 12 firms to pay restitution totaling more than $4 million and fines totaling more than $2.6 million for failing to apply available sales charge discounts to customers' purchases of Unit Investment Trusts (UITs), and related supervisory failures.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined MetLife Securities, Inc., and three of its affiliates a total of $1.2 million for failing to establish an adequate supervisory system for the review of brokers' email correspondence with the public. The fine also resolved charges of failing to establish adequate supervisory procedures relating to broker participation in outside business activities and private securities transactions.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: FINRA fined 25 broker-dealers a total of $2,145,000 for failures related to their completion of FINRA's (then NASD's) firm self-assessment of mutual fund breakpoint discount compliance.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD fined Chase Investment Services Corporation of Chicago and MetLife Securities, Inc. of New York $500,000 each for failing to establish systems and procedures to supervise the sales of 529 College Savings Plans.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed a $5 million fine against MetLife Securities, Inc., New England Securities, Inc. and Walnut Street Securities, Inc.-all owned by MetLife, Inc.-for providing inaccurate and misleading information to NASD, allowing late trading of mutual funds, failing to produce emails in a timely fashion and other conduct that violates NASD's rules.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
